items.title: Full Moon
items.content_html:
I was lucky to see scenery straight out of a Ghibli movie in real life.

What comes to mind when you see the full moon?

For me, itâ€™s always this passage from The Sheltering Sky:

Because we don’t know when we will die
We get to think of life as an inexhaustible well
Yet everything happens only a certain number of times
And a very small number, really
How many more times will you remember a certain afternoon of your childhood
Some afternoon that is so deeply a part of your being that you can’t even conceive your life without it?
Perhaps four or five times more
Perhaps not even that
How many more times will you watch the full moon rise?
Perhaps twenty, and yet it all seems limitless
â€” Paul Bowles

ğŸ§ fullmoon (immersion 2023)
ğŸ§‘ğŸ»â€ğŸ¤ Ryuichi Sakamoto
ğŸ’¿ async - immersion 2023 (2024)

items.title: A Little Thought on "Bad Habits"
items.content_html:
When a person cannot satisfy their deeper emotional needs, like love, security, belonging, or purpose, they often redirect that emptiness into various substitute desires / compensatory behaviours that afford immediate pleasures or comforts. These substitutes can become excessive, inappropriate, or addictive, thus often referred to as “bad habits.” Examples include:

  • Sexual desire (overly seeking sex)
  • Material desire (shopping, hoarding, etc.)
  • Food-related desires (overeating, binge eating, eating disorders, etc.)
  • Substance use (smoking, drinking alcohol)
  • Behavioural addictions (such as video games)

These compensations can feel soothing in the short term, but they donâ€™t address the root cause. Over time, they can spiral into addictions or unhealthy patterns, which only widen the gap between what a person truly needs and what theyâ€™re chasing.

Itâ€™s clearly a vicious cycle: unmet needs â†’ temporary coping behaviours â†’ guilt/shame or further emptiness â†’ even stronger cravings. Breaking this cycle usually requires not just self-control, but also self-awareness and sometimes therapy to identify the underlying emotional void.

Addictions and compulsive behaviours arenâ€™t just “bad habits.” Theyâ€™re often signals that something deeper in us is being ignored. If we learn to listen to those signals instead of numbing them, we can actually grow in healthier ways.
items.content_text:
When a person cannot satisfy their deeper emotional needs, like love, security, belonging, or purpose, they often redirect that emptiness into various substitute desires / compensatory behaviours that afford immediate pleasures or comforts. These substitutes can become excessive, inappropriate, or addictive, thus often referred to as "bad habits." Examples include:
- Sexual desire (overly seeking sex)
- Material desire (shopping, hoarding, etc.)
- Food-related desires (overeating, binge eating, eating disorders, etc.)
- Substance use (smoking, drinking alcohol)
- Behavioural addictions (such as video games)  

These compensations can feel soothing in the short term, but they donâ€™t address the root cause. Over time, they can spiral into addictions or unhealthy patterns, which only widen the gap between what a person truly needs and what theyâ€™re chasing.  

Itâ€™s clearly a vicious cycle: unmet needs â†’ temporary coping behaviours â†’ guilt/shame or further emptiness â†’ even stronger cravings. Breaking this cycle usually requires not just self-control, but also self-awareness and sometimes therapy to identify the underlying emotional void.

Addictions and compulsive behaviours arenâ€™t just "bad habits." Theyâ€™re often signals that something deeper in us is being ignored. If we learn to listen to those signals instead of numbing them, we can actually grow in healthier ways.

Iâ€™ve been a proud Endel Premium user since the fall of 2020. As of now, I have spent 1709 days with the app and averaged about 4 hours of use every night.

I honestly canâ€™t sleep properly without my CPAP or Endelâ€™s Sleep soundscape. This wonderful app has been part of my sleep routine for a few weeks shy of five years.

items.content_html: It looked like the links and icons on my site were shifting upward in dark mode on hover, but nothing changed in the CSS. Light mode had no issues. After some digging, I realized it was an optical illusion caused by the colour contrast. Changing the hover colour fixed it.
items.content_text: It looked like the links and icons on my site were shifting upward in dark mode on hover, but nothing changed in the CSS. Light mode had no issues. After some digging, I realized it was an optical illusion caused by the colour contrast. Changing the hover colour fixed it.

items.title: Which will die first, Vega, Altair, or the Sun?
items.content_html:
Among the three stars â€” Vega, Altair, and the Sun â€” Vega will die first, followed by Altair, and then our Sun, which will be the last to reach the end of its life.

The primary reason for this sequence lies in their masses and lifespans, which are inversely related: the more massive a star, the faster it burns through its nuclear fuel and the shorter its lifespan.

Stellar Mass and Lifespan: The Trade-Off

To understand this better, letâ€™s compare their masses and expected main-sequence lifespans:

Star Spectral Type Mass (Sun = 1) Estimated Lifespan (Main Sequence)
Vega A0V ~2.1 ~500 million years
Altair A7V ~1.8 ~1â€“2 billion years
Sun G2V 1.0 ~10 billion years
  • Vega, the brightest star in the constellation Lyra, is more than twice as massive as the Sun. It is a relatively young star, around 450 million years old, and is already about halfway through its main-sequence life. At this pace, itâ€™s expected to exhaust its core hydrogen in less than 500 million years from now.
  • Altair, the brightest star in Aquila, is slightly less massive than Vega and rotates very rapidly. Its mass gives it a longer lifespan than Vegaâ€”about 1 to 2 billion years in total.
  • The Sun, our middle-aged yellow dwarf, has an estimated total lifespan of about 10 billion years. Currently, it is about 4.6 billion years old, with roughly 5 billion years remaining before it leaves the main sequence.

Why Bigger Stars Die Sooner

Massive stars have stronger gravitational pressure at their cores, which leads to higher temperatures and faster nuclear fusion. Although they have more fuel to burn, they burn it much more rapidly, dramatically shortening their lifespans.

In contrast, stars like the Sun burn fuel more slowly and steadily, giving them far longer to shine.

Conclusion

Vega will die first, likely within a few hundred million years. Altair will follow, and the Sun will live the longest of the three. Their fates serve as a reminder of the delicate balance between mass, energy, and time in stellar evolution.

by ChatGPT GPT-4o

Among the three stars â€” Vega, Altair, and the Sun â€” Vega will die first, followed by Altair, and then our Sun, which will be the last to reach the end of its life. The primary reason for this sequence lies in their masses and lifespans, which are inversely related: the more massive a star, the faster it burns through its nuclear fuel and the shorter its lifespan. ### Stellar Mass and Lifespan: The Trade-Off To understand this better, letâ€™s compare their masses and expected main-sequence lifespans: | Star | Spectral Type | Mass (Sun = 1) | Estimated Lifespan (Main Sequence) | | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | | Vega | A0V | ~2.1 | ~500 million years | | Altair |A7V | ~1.8 | ~1â€“2 billion years | | Sun | G2V | 1.0| ~10 billion years | - Vega, the brightest star in the constellation Lyra, is more than twice as massive as the Sun. It is a relatively young star, around 450 million years old, and is already about halfway through its main-sequence life. At this pace, itâ€™s expected to exhaust its core hydrogen in less than 500 million years from now. - Altair, the brightest star in Aquila, is slightly less massive than Vega and rotates very rapidly. Its mass gives it a longer lifespan than Vegaâ€”about 1 to 2 billion years in total. - The Sun, our middle-aged yellow dwarf, has an estimated total lifespan of about 10 billion years. Currently, it is about 4.6 billion years old, with roughly 5 billion years remaining before it leaves the main sequence. ### Why Bigger Stars Die Sooner Massive stars have stronger gravitational pressure at their cores, which leads to higher temperatures and faster nuclear fusion. Although they have more fuel to burn, they burn it much more rapidly, dramatically shortening their lifespans. In contrast, stars like the Sun burn fuel more slowly and steadily, giving them far longer to shine. ### Conclusion Vega will die first, likely within a few hundred million years. Altair will follow, and the Sun will live the longest of the three. Their fates serve as a reminder of the delicate balance between mass, energy, and time in stellar evolution.

Iâ€™ve switched back to the 24-hour notation on my main site, blog, and every other site I control. Iâ€™ve always been a fan of the 24-hour system, and the Canadian government encourages its use too. Soâ€¦ I figure doing a bit of mental math (like remembering that 00 is 12 a.m., 12 is 12 p.m., and subtracting 12 if the hourâ€™s over 12) isnâ€™t that hard, eh?

A neighbour had an Amazon package swiped off his porch. Someone across the street caught it on her security cam and let him know. She asked what was taken and how much it was worth. Turns out, it was a security camera â€” meant to stop exactly this kind of thing.

items.title: Remnant
items.content_html:
The earthquake struck when I was six.
I survived.
Most of my classmates didnâ€™t.

Now Iâ€™m in college, in another city.
Whenever I return home, I pass their parents on the street.
They stop me,
their eyes scanning me â€”
as if searching for what might have been.
Then, with a gentle, aching smile, they say,
â€œYouâ€™ve grown so much.â€
items.content_text:
The earthquake struck when I was six.  
I survived.  
Most of my classmates didnâ€™t.  

Now Iâ€™m in college, in another city.  
Whenever I return home, I pass their parents on the street.  
They stop me,  
their eyes scanning me â€”  
as if searching for what might have been.  
Then, with a gentle, aching smile, they say,  
â€œYouâ€™ve grown so much.â€

items.title: My 12 Lessons of Life
items.content_html:
Lesson 01: I am not the centre of everyoneâ€™s attention
Lesson 02: Learn to embrace farewells
Lesson 03: No one will care about me forever
Lesson 04: Master my emotions
Lesson 05: Love myself before I love anyone else
Lesson 06: Health is my greatest wealth
Lesson 07: Accept every regret with grace
Lesson 08: Save my anger for what truly matters
Lesson 09: Embrace my own imperfections
Lesson 10: Learn to find joy in solitude
Lesson 11: Brave souls savour the world
Lesson 12: Always stay true to myself

items.content_html:
Trapped in the claws of the bear
And I wonder
Will all things be empty again?

Bare hands with my winter fears
Cold till it burns
You’ll be blowing away the frostbites
When we’ll return

items.title: Snacks
items.content_html:
Granny hands me a bag of snacks,
edges soft, the crunch long gone.
I look at Mom and ask,
â€œDid they expire?â€
She smiles, half-lost in thought,
â€œNo, love â€” we just came home too late.â€

For a one-time payment of CA$199.99 (or [US$97.99 on StackSocial](https://www.stacksocial.com/sales/pdf-expert-premium-plan-lifetime)), customers have no access to their future big updates and new features, including the AI assistant. Also, itâ€™s macOS only; the mobile apps are not included.

items.content_text:
Oopsâ€¦ Just found out that Silicon Valleyâ€™s trendy social media app [Airchat](https://apps.apple.com/ca/app/airchat-just-talk/id1469462351) is already toast. Its [official website](https://air.chat) has shut down. That was fast!

While [Elie Steinbock](https://www.indiehackers.com/elie222) believed that [Airchat would change social media forever](https://www.indiehackers.com/post/why-airchat-will-change-social-media-forever-2caaa3336f), Elaine Moore was right on the money â€” [Airchatâ€™s viral success will not last](https://www.ft.com/content/177d2cb8-777b-48e4-8abf-2f6057aa9c4b).

items.content_html:
Back in 1980, KFC had around 6,000 locations across 48 countries, pulling in $2 billion a year ($2 billion in 1980 is roughly $7.66 billion in todayâ€™s dollars).

Fast forward to 2023, and the brand had grown to nearly 30,000 outlets in 145 countries, with annual sales reaching $2.83 billion.
items.content_text:
Back in **1980**, KFC had around **6,000** locations across **48** countries, pulling in **$2 billion** a year ($2 billion in 1980 is roughly $7.66 billion in todayâ€™s dollars).

Fast forward to **2023**, and the brand had grown to nearly **30,000** outlets in **145** countries, with annual sales reaching **$2.83 billion**.

items.content_html:
JavaScript short date-time format:

  • United States: Tue, 02/18/2025, 1:58 AM EST
  • Canada: Tue, 2025-02-18, 1:58 a.m. EST

Without a doubt, the Canadian short date looks cleaner and more visually appealing, and the â€œa.m.â€ (or â€œp.m.â€) style has a classic touch. However, itâ€™s four characters long. Also, in the long date-time format, the word â€œatâ€ appears between the date and time, whereas in the short version, itâ€™s simply replaced by a comma. I dislike seeing more than one comma in a timestamp, so on this site, what you actually see is a hybrid version: Tue, 2025-02-18 @ 1:58 AM EST.

items.content_html: Places like Value Village always leave me with mixed emotions. As soon as I walk in, I feel a rush of excitement. Thereâ€™s an eclectic assortment of items, many of them surprisingly decent and offered at affordable prices. But in the end, I always feel a bit sentimental. These items were likely cherished by their original owners at one time, only to end up being sold for next to nothing. Itâ€™s bittersweet â€” and in a way, it feels like a reflection of human relationships.

Itâ€™s bittersweet â€” and in a way, it feels like a reflection of human relationships.

items.title: If I named this post Â«Unconditional LoveÂ» it would come off as a clichÃ© but honestly thatâ€™s what itâ€™s all about
items.content_html:
During the chaos of my parentsâ€™ divorce (when I was around 11), my uncles on my motherâ€™s side (or maybe my grandmotherâ€”I canâ€™t quite remember, but it doesnâ€™t really matter since they shared the same values) offered to take me to a theme park out of town. But shortly after, they had a change of heart. They wanted to see who I would end up living with. Basically, if I had chosen to stay with my dad, whom they saw as their sworn enemy, they wouldnâ€™t have bothered with me or the trip. I have to admit, for most of my adult life, I didnâ€™t think anything was wrong with thatâ€”itâ€™s kind of like how economics works: your employer is likely to withdraw benefits when they know youâ€™re intent on leaving for another employer, seeing it as a way to avoid needless losses.

However, when I casually mentioned this to my landlord (yes, Iâ€™ve had many heart-to-hearts with this older lady), she was surprised, even a bit confused. She was like, â€œI donâ€™t know what they were thinking, but if you were my grandchild and I knew you were leaving us to live with your dad, Iâ€™d want to take you anywhere you wanted and give you the best I couldâ€”because I wouldnâ€™t know when Iâ€™d see you again.â€

My eyes welled up. I was genuinely shocked to hear such a different perspective. Some people strictly prioritize benefits over kindness, while others donâ€™t really care about gains and losses. It really got me thinking a lot about family values and what unconditional love truly meant. At one point, I even felt like I didnâ€™t really know what love was.

I couldnâ€™t choose the family I was born into, but I can choose to carry that conversation with me forever.

I couldnâ€™t choose the family I was born into, but I can choose to carry that conversation with me forever.

items.content_html: I wonder if there is a way for these music streaming platforms to prevent what I call “namespace pollution.” This term refers to different artists sharing the same name and being grouped together on a single artist page, especially when they are mononymous or have very common names. Itâ€™s really frustrating because, despite having the same name, these artists often create music in completely different genres and languages!
items.content_text: I wonder if there is a way for these music streaming platforms to prevent what I call "**namespace pollution**." This term refers to different artists sharing the same name and being grouped together on a single artist page, especially when they are mononymous or have very common names. Itâ€™s really frustrating because, despite having the same name, these artists often create music in completely different genres and languages!

Anders Celsius, the proposer of the degree Celsius, died at the age of 42.

Daniel Gabriel Fahrenheit would have believed his opponent had died at 107.

items.content_html: Once I bought a frosted glass for $12 at IKEA. It was beautiful but a bit too big and didnâ€™t have a handle. If I drank water from it before a meal Iâ€™d feel too full to eat. Just way too big. Weeks later I got an IKEA flyer and saw itâ€™d been reduced to $7 and advertised as a vase.
